nytimes_articles.abstract: Clare Eichner of Wisconsin completed a rare sweep of the middle-distance races at the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships, both indoors and out, when she won the 1,500 meters tonight. But even that wasn't enough to keep Louisiana State from winning its seventh consecutive women's team title.   L.S.U. scored 93 points to more than double Wisconsin's second-place score of 44 points.

nytimes_articles.headline: Land of the Raj
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: Many happy memories were brought back by Julie Sahni's article about India. Most people are unaware of this "hill station" resort in southern India. Darjeeling and Simla are two names that people are much more familiar with; however, these are in the northern part of the country.   I was sorry that Ms. Sahni did not include Coonoor, a nearby town, the other major community in the Nilgiri Hills. Coonoor compares very favorably with Ootacamund as a resort area and should not be overlooked..

nytimes_articles.headline: Adventures in Russia'a Far East
nytimes_articles.abstract: The loosening of travel restrictions to the Russian Far East has spawned a number of new adventure tours to places formerly closed to foreigners. The destinations include the Kamchatka Peninsula, the strategic military area over which Korean Airlines Flight 007 flew before it was shot down by the Russians in 1983.    "Crossroads of Continents -- Remote Alaska and the Russian Far East Above the Arctic Circle," is an 11-day voyage aboard Clipper Adventure Cruises' 138-passenger World Discoverer, a ship built especially for navigation through ice-strewn waters. The ship, which will follow 18th- and 19th-century exploration routes, departs Nome July 11, 21 and 31 and Aug. 10. Stops in Russia include the whaling village of Novoye Chaplino, the town of Provideniya and Uelen, an isolated Chukchi village, the easternmost outpost of the Russian continent. Guides will be on hand to identify wildlife, such as Pacific walruses, whales and polar bears, and to lecture on Russian, Aleut, Chukchi and Yuit culture and history. Cost per person, double occupancy, is $3,500 to $5,200 and does not include air fare. Information: Clipper Adventure Cruises, 7711 Bonhomme Avenue, St. Louis, Mo. 63105; (800) 325-0010.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEW PLANS READY FOR SPACE STATION
nytimes_articles.abstract: The nine-year, $9 billion space-station program enters a crucial phase this week as the Clinton Administration ends a four-month bid to slim down the proposed outpost for orbiting astronauts while weighing full participation by the Russians.   The process of redesign, as full of zigs and zags as the beleaguered station program itself, has produced three alternatives, each progressively cheaper than the $31 billion, 350-foot design that the Clinton White House inherited from the Bush Administration.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Focus Is on Delmore Schwartz
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I appreciate the favorable review by Michael Milburn of my edition of "Delmore Schwartz and James Laughlin: Selected Letters" (May 9). Mr. Milburn expressed some concern about the "imbalance" of the number of letters by Schwartz versus those by Laughlin.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEW CLUES FOUND IN FATAL ILLNESSES
nytimes_articles.abstract: Researchers sounded notably if guardedly optimistic today that they had indeed found the cause of a mysterious flu-like illness responsible for killing 11 and gravely sickening 7 others in New Mexico and Arizona.   When scientists announced Friday night that they believed the disease was caused by a rodent virus called hanta virus, they were hesitant and quick to caveat every word. Today, the caveats had been cut roughly in half. "It has not been conclusively confirmed, and there's a lot we do not know," Dr. Fred Koster of the University of New Mexico Medical Center said at a news conference here today. "But there's a very good possibility we're seeing the agent that could cause this type of syndrome."

nytimes_articles.headline: Mary LaTulip, John L. Troost
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mary Lauren LaTulip, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin LaTulip of West Chester, Pa., was married yesterday to John Laurens Troost, the son of Joan Troost of Seekonk, Mass., and the late John Troost. The Rev. Thomas E. Moye, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.   Ms. LaTulip, who is keeping her name, is a systems manager for Advantage Inc., a temporary-employment agency in New York. She graduated from Columbia University, as did her husband. Her father is the branch manager, in Columbia, Md., of the Reliance Insurance Company. Her mother, Carolyn LaTulip, is an elementary-school teacher at East Ward School in Downingtown, Pa.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tracy Callaghan, John Torrente Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tracy Lynn Callaghan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Callaghan of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to John Joseph Torrente Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Torrente Sr. of Ridgewood. The Rev. Arvin Ten Brink performed the Dutch Reformed ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.   Mrs. Torrente, 25, is an administrative assistant in the institutional credit department at Bear, Stearns & Company, the securities brokerage. Her father is the president of SPG Group, the securities clearing division of Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Westchester Q&A;: Janet S. Walker;
Assessing Reactions to School Budgets
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AFTER two years of struggling to keep school taxes down despite severe cuts in state aid and increases in enrollment, many Westchester school districts this year proposed tax hikes of 5 to 10 percent and even more. The answer from the voters has been mixed: budgets have been defeated in Edgemont, Greenburgh, Harrison, Ossining, Somers and Tuckahoe, among others, but approved in districts like Scarsdale, Ardsley, Mount Pleasant, Bronxville and Elmsford. 

These elections came in the wake of widespread statewide publicity about perks given to school administrators and a state report that concluded that some districts, including a number in Westchester, have too many administrators. Last month Gov. Mario M. Cuomo appointed a nine-member commission to investigate how state money is spent by schools.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brooklyn Father Arrested in Child's Death
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Brooklyn man was arrested and charged yesterday with the murder of his 2 1/2-year-old son, the police said.   The man, Christopher Willis, 28, was arrested at 8 A.M. near Atlantic Avenue in Crown Heights just hours after the baby died at St. John's Hospital, said Capt. William F. Plackenmeyer of the Brooklyn Detective Bureau.

nytimes_articles.headline: Telling Difference
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   Two incidents in the 1993 N.B.A. playoffs have shown me the difference between the Knicks and the Bulls.

nytimes_articles.headline: G.O.P. IN VIRGINIA PICKS FALL SLATE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Virginia Republicans, always among the most conservative in the country, moved even further to the right today as they nominated candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor and Attorney General in this fall's election.   Meeting in a convention here, 13,000 party delegates chose former Representative George Allen for the top spot on the ticket, then picked Mike Farris, a northern Virginia lawyer, for the Lieutenant Governor's slot.

nytimes_articles.headline: E. C. Castleman, Kevin T. Halpin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth Cross Castleman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Castleman of Little Silver, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin Thomas Halpin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas K. Halpin of Port Monmouth, N.J. The Rev. Mark Van Sant performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. George's by-the-River in Rumson, N.J.   Mrs. Halpin, 30, is the director of the New Horizon Preschool in Port Monmouth. She graduated from Monmouth College. Her father is a managing director of the Bankers Trust Company in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART REVIEW;
Printmaking and Atelier 17
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THIS country's debt to Atelier 17, the experimental printmaking workshop, deserves to be more widely known. Fortunately, "Atelier 17 and the New York Avant-Garde," an exhibition at the Pollock-Krasner House and Study Center in East Hampton, offers both visual treats and a great many insights into the workshop's significance.

When its founder, the English-born painter and engraver Stanley William Hayter, moved Atelier 17 from Paris to New York in 1940 because of World War II, he created an environment that commingled European expatriate artists -- many had already made prints with him in Paris -- with younger Americans eager to explore new ideas. Ernst, Matta, Miro, Tanguy and Masson were among the Europeans, and Pollock, Motherwell and Rothko were among the Americans.

nytimes_articles.headline: Island Quiltmaker Masters an Art of Old
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JOYCE MURRIN of East Marion did not set out to be a quilter, just as she never had any overt ambition to be an artist. But over the last two decades she has become nationally known, acclaimed for her innovative, mostly abstract quilts.

With works in museums and important collections, her list of scholarly articles, pieces that have won prizes in exhibitions and scores of students, Mrs. Murrin has become an important figure in quilting.

nytimes_articles.headline: Michele Sherman, Barry L. Entner
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michele D. Sherman, the daughter of Myrna and Joel Sherman of Leonia, N.J., was married last evening in New York to Barry L. Entner, a son of Fritzie Entner of Sharon, Mass., and the late Sam Entner. Rabbi Nat Benjamin performed the ceremony at the Hotel Macklowe.   Mrs. Sherman-Entner, 27, graduated from Ithaca College. She is the director of national accounts for the Nat Sherman Company, a tobacconist in New York. Her father is the president of the company, which was founded by her paternal grandfather, the late Nat Sherman, in 1930.

nytimes_articles.headline: Top Graduates in Science Also Put Dreams on Hold
nytimes_articles.abstract: These are unsettling job-hunting times, even for the certifiably brilliant progeny of the nation's top schools in science and engineering.    Seniors who had their hearts set on creating the technologies of the next century are having trouble just lining up job interviews, and fresh new Ph.D.'s are settling for temporary teaching jobs offering little prospect of the security of tenure.

nytimes_articles.headline:
FOCUS;
Tenfold Growth for a Tiny Bay Area City?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Just two weeks after the City Council of this farming community 40 miles east of San Francisco gave its approval to the largest residential development in local history -- a 1,031-house subdivision by A.G. Spanos Construction Company of Stockton -- it approved the second-largest. It will have 940 houses. Hancock Construction Company of Saratoga is the builder. 

Still to come is a proposal by the Cowell Foundation, a San Francisco charitable organization, to develop the 4,900-acre Cowell Ranch adjacent to this city into a 7,500-home community complete with schools, parks and retail and employment centers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Back in the Swim With Fresh Air Fund
nytimes_articles.abstract: While staying with a Massachusetts family last summer, Keenen Jackson, 11, of Staten Island, learned how to fish but not how to tell a fish story.   "I've caught fish in the pond," he announced proudly at a pizza party recently for Fresh Air Fund children from Staten Island. But, holding his index fingers a few inches apart, he admitted, "They were really little fish."

nytimes_articles.headline: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: HORSEMAN OF THE YEAR   County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke will acquire the title "Horseman of the Year" today, to be bestowed on him during ceremonies at 10 A.M. at the North Ridge Equestrian Center, 960 California Road in Eastchester.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1 Standard for All
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   If The Times's reports about Michael Jordan's gambling activities are correct, then the National Basketball Association should suspend Jordan for one year. Bulls forward Horace Grant is right: We should not have one standard for Michael Jordan and a wholly different standard for everybody else. A double standard communicates the message that, as long as you are a great player, you can do anything you want and get away with it. By suspending Michael Jordan for gambling activities, the N.B.A. will safeguard the integrity and credibility of professional basketball and also send an important and much needed message about character. HAVEN BRADFORD GOW Arlington Heights, Ill.

nytimes_articles.headline: Faye Fisher, Alan Zwiebel
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rabbi and Mrs. David Fisher have announced the engagement of their daughter Faye Fisher to Alan H. Zwiebel, a son of Mrs. Harry Garber of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Louis J. Zwiebel. A spring 1994 wedding is planned.   Ms. Fisher is a restaurant advertising consultant in New York with Transmedia Network Inc., a financial services company for restaurants. She and her fiance graduated from Brooklyn College, from which she also received a master's degree in drama.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The View From: Scarsdale;
Sunday Morning at the Movies (for Non-Sun Worshipers)
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WOULD anyone go to the movies at 10 o'clock on a summer Sunday morning? Marilyn Ackerman and Beth Kochen, who run the Westchester Cinema Club, are betting that the answer is yes.

For 13 years in the fall, winter and spring, the club has shown films that Mrs. Ackerman describes as artistic, intellectual, geared for select audiences on Sunday mornings at the 350-seat Fine Arts Cinema here. Now, for the first time, the club is starting a summer series. The opening offering, on June 27, is "A Brief History of Time," a documentary about Stephen Hawking, a noted British physicist who has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International 3-21  U.N. TROOPS CLASH WITH SOMALIS

nytimes_articles.headline: North and South Join Classic Tale's Study
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SUSAN ROSS, an English teacher at Yorktown High School, became dissatisfied last year with the way she had been teaching "To Kill a Mockingbird," the classic novel of a white girl growing up in the segregated South. 

The 1960 work by Harper Lee about a small-town lawyer's defense in the 1930's of a black man falsely accused of raping a white woman is told from his daughter's perspective. The story was based on her father's career.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sallie Saunders And John Colucci
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sallie Alyce Saunders, a manager in the human resources department at Time Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to John Anthony Colucci, a vice president of new business development in Pelham, N.Y., for Gulfstream Aerospace, a corporate jet manufacturer based in Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Jack Roche performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Lawyer Vanishes
nytimes_articles.abstract:
PLEADING GUILTY
By Scott Turow.
386 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ms. Friedman, Mr. Kushner
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stephanie Paige Friedman, the daughter of Dr. Melvin M. Friedman and Joyce Ezrine, both of Baltimore, was married there yesterday to Thomas Nicholas Kushner, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Kushner. The Rev. John S. Witulich, a Roman Catholic priest, and Cantor Harold Levy officiated at the Woodholme Country Club.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Fugitive's Tale Sheds Light On China Today
nytimes_articles.abstract: One of the astonishing facts of the Tiananmen Square protest in Beijing four years ago was that 8 of the 21 students on the security police's most-wanted list managed to evade arrest and eventually to escape to the West. It happens, moreover, that China, at least until recently, has had a security apparatus so ruthlessly efficient that escape was hardly thought of, much less attempted. And so, the question is: How did the students do it?    At least a partial answer is provided by "Escape From China," a 57-minute documentary by Iris F. Kung, the pseudonym of a Chinese television reporter now living in the United States. The film, which will be shown Friday and Saturday at the Anthology Film Archives, tells the story of 25-year-old Zhang Boli, one of the most prominent of the student leaders and the person who hid in China longer than any other of the hunted dissidents.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The Deadly Sins/Sloth;
Nearer, My Couch, to Thee
nytimes_articles.abstract:
When the sun blazes down on the hot sidewalk by day, and the sidewalk radiates it back by night, perhaps your thoughts, panicky with heat, plunge toward the idea of never-ending swelter, of eternal damnation to a windless city. At such a time, you might even start considering the traditional path to such damnation, the deadly sins -- sloth, anger, lust, envy, gluttony, pride and avarice. How often we have been told that our godless age has lost its sense of sin! 

But is that really so? Have the rules changed? Have the sins changed? 

Or is sin an idea whose time has finally passed?

nytimes_articles.headline: NOTES
nytimes_articles.abstract: The latest George Michael video has a piercing quality -- as in pierced lips and pierced noses. Bellybuttons and eyebrows, too. "We shot all these hip-hop rave kids at subway stations," said Marcus Nispel, 30, the video's German director. "They are the guys who come up with style. They go to Woolworth's and the Salvation Army, and they make something out of it." Mr. Nispel has interspersed these urban scenes with cartoon images that spoof popular products like Tide and Mr. Clean. "It's about how the marketing of these fashion trends went really, really fast," he said. "How a trend comes out, and three months later it's a whole floor at Bloomingdale's."

nytimes_articles.headline: Off-Duty Officer Shot
nytimes_articles.abstract: An off-duty police officer was shot in Staten Island yesterday as an assailant robbed him outside a bank, the police said. The officer, Detective Dominick Trancucci, 42, was approaching the Gateway State Bank on Forest Avenue about 5:30 P.M. to deposit about $2,000 into the bank's drop slot when he was accosted by a man carrying a handgun, said Sgt. John McCluskey, a police spokesman. Detective Trancucci struggled for the gun, said Sergeant McCluskey, and was shot in his left shoulder. Detective Trancucci, a 19-year veteran of the police force, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital in Staten Island, where he was listed in stable condition last night, said Sergeant McCluskey. His assailant fled with the cash.

nytimes_articles.headline: MORE PEOPLE VIEW CLINTON AS LIBERAL AS HE SEEKS CENTER
nytimes_articles.abstract: As President Clinton struggles to return to the centrist policies that won the election, an increased number of Americans view him as a liberal, and many say his economic plan relies too heavily on raising taxes and would do little to help the economy, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.   Most Americans do not appear convinced by Mr. Clinton's repeated efforts to show that his economic remedies will place a heavier burden on rich people than on the middle class. And they have grown increasingly skeptical about the fairness and effectiveness of the plan.

nytimes_articles.headline: French Foursome Has Bermuda Bowl Hopes
nytimes_articles.abstract: BASED on past performance, there is a strong possibility that the final of the 1993 World Championship, which will be contested for the Bermuda Bowl in Santiago, Chile, in September, will be between the United States and France. That would repeat the 1992 final in Salsomaggiore, Italy, when the French were victorious.   The Americans and the French have met on 19 official or semi-official occasions. There have been six French victories, four of them en route to world titles, and 12 American victories. A 1932 match was abandoned as a draw after a dispute.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public & Private; Political Illiteracy
nytimes_articles.abstract: There's a certain kind of conversation you have from time to time at parties in New York about a new book. The word "banal" sometimes rears its by-now banal head; you say "underedited," I say "derivative." The conversation goes around and around various literary criticisms, and by the time it moves on one thing is clear: no one read the book, we just read the reviews.    A variation on those conversations has taken place in Washington over the last month about the past opinions of an accomplished and ill-treated woman named Lani Guinier.

nytimes_articles.headline: Weapons Measure Hits a Roadblock in Hartford
nytimes_articles.abstract: A bill to ban the sale of semiautomatic military-style assault rifles in Connecticut tumbled into parliamentary limbo late Friday night in the state Senate, clouding the proposal's chances with time running out before the General Assembly's adjournment on Wednesday.   Sportsmen's groups and lobbyists for the National Rifle Association, which has launched a major effort to kill the bill, were jubilant but still remained cautious today. The bill's proponents were confused by the turn of events.

nytimes_articles.headline: The View From: Hampton; How a Small Town Reveals Americans' Values
nytimes_articles.abstract: OCCASIONALLY Janet and James Robertson asked about the history of their village. One day, Mrs. Robertson recalled, "the past came to our door. Wendell Davis just came, with a great big box full of stuff." Added her husband: "It had clearly not been packed, just dumped. We pulled out a Yale catalogue from 1820." The couple would pull much more from the past.    The Robertsons live in Hampton, where two rows of sturdy houses line a little stretch of road through the hills of northeastern Connecticut. In 1967 they bought an 18th-century house there from Mr. Davis and his brothers, whose family had bought it in 1804.  They got to know Mr. Davis, but they didn't know that for 150 years his ancestors -- Taintors and Davises -- had saved just about everything, including college catalogues, personal letters, business records, newspapers, pamphlets, pictures and an 1853 key to "Uncle Tom's Cabin." The family removed all of it before selling the house.

nytimes_articles.headline: Perspectives: Renewing the Branches; Carnegie's Library Parade Marches On
nytimes_articles.abstract: A GRATIFYING sight awaits Andrew Carnegie should he decide to materialize on Amboy Road in the Tottenville section of Staten Island. A library built with his money in 1904 has been overhauled at a cost of $1.9 million by the Department of General Services. It reopened in March -- repaired, restored and braced for the brave new audio-visual world of the 90's.   The branch is one of at least 65 libraries built in New York City with the 19th-century industrialist's money, a fraction of more than 2,000 he paid for around the world. In New York, 52 of these buildings survive as libraries. None so far has received so extensive a restorative treatment as the one operating in an old-Americana setting at 7430 Amboy Road, at the southernmost tip of Staten Island.

nytimes_articles.headline: Eileen Weiler, Robert Judell
nytimes_articles.abstract: Eileen Weiler, a reading specialist at the Chapin School, was married on Wednesday to Robert Buchman Judell, the president and chief executive of James Thompson & Company, textile manufacturers. Both work in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Life for An Old Rivalry?
nytimes_articles.abstract: AFTER 60 years of vying for dominance in 35-millimeter photography, Leica and Contax, the German camera makers, may be poised to enter another round. The stage has been set with the introduction of the newest Contax single-lens-reflex camera, the ST.    The ST has some features that just may stir the competitive spirit at Leica. One is a ceramic pressure plate, which the company says keeps the film flatter than the plate in any other camera and does not react to temperature or humidity. And all the analogue dials on top of the camera can be lighted at night with the push of a button; the light goes off after 16 seconds, avoiding battery drain.

nytimes_articles.headline: Father and Son on a College Team
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN John Black Jr., the top-seeded player on the Mercer County Community College men's team, stepped onto a tennis court this season, his father was nearby. But the senior John Black wasn't in the stands cheering or on the sidelines coaching.

As the second-seeded player on the team, he competed alongside his son. And when his son played doubles, the 50-year-old father was his partner.

nytimes_articles.headline:
DINING OUT;
Chinese Cuisine Worthy of Sampling
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE three-year-old Peking Pavilion in Red Bank is in an attractive two-story building that once housed the Oakland Street School and several previous restaurants. Now, the large white foo dogs that stand guard at the foot of the steps are obvious indications that Chinese food is served here. As if that isn't enough, a life-size reproduction of a terra-cotta warrior, like those found buried near Beijing, is also near the entrance.

Inside are brick walls, black lacquer and etched mirror dividers, plants and indoor trees. Tables are nicely spaced and attractively set, and service is black tie and efficient. Add better-than-average Chinese food, and this Monmouth County restaurant becomes worthy of a detour.

nytimes_articles.headline: Six in Sixth Deep-Six the Drowning Mets
nytimes_articles.abstract: The six stayed up on the scoreboard, fat and forever. The six -- the number of runs the Astros scored in the sixth inning to win, 7-5 -- was the latest product of Mets disaster, the most recent evidence that there is not much more to their 1993 season but the most joyless or ludicrous sorts of calculations.   Can the Mets lose 100 games? Can the club be mathematically eliminated by the All-Star Game break? When exactly will the parade of promotions from the minors begin? How many hours are left before Manager Dallas Green resigns and goes to join his wife in Tibet? Weakening in the Sixth    The Mets have specialized in provoking such fatalism. Tonight's sixth inning was the heart of the latest darkness. Bret Saberhagen, starting despite residual weakness after a bout with bronchitis, was nonetheless vulnerable in the sixth. Steve Finley tripled to lead off and scored on a groundout. The bases, momentarily cleared, were soon overpopulated and cleared again, a great migration of Astros that would transform a 5-2 lead to a 7-5 deficit.

nytimes_articles.headline: Correction
nytimes_articles.abstract: A response to a question in the Q & A column on May 23 about a co-op board's rejection of a potential buyer without explanation referred incorrectly to the board's obligations. A board is not obliged to give a reason for rejection.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ellen Wasserman, David Cangialosi
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ellen Wasserman, a daughter of Maurice and Martha Wasserman of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday in White Plains to David Edward Cangialosi, a son of Lillian Cangialosi of Emerson, N.J., and the late Joseph D. Cangialosi. Dr. Matthew Ies Spetter, the leader of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Women's Club of White Plains.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Greenhorn Takes On Grand Teton
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ON paper, it looked seductively simple: two days of basic climbing school followed by a guided two-day ascent of Wyoming's 13,766-foot-high Grand Teton, the crown jewel of one of the most spectacular mountain ranges in North America. For years, a college chum who lives in Jackson, Wyo., had been trying to lure me to the Rockies, to no avail. Then he mailed me a brochure from Exum Mountain Guides, which leads greenhorns up the scenic trail first blazed by Glen Exum back in 1931. All it took was one look at the color photos of the staggering vistas and the beatific grins on the climbers' faces, and I was ready to go. But not alone. If I was going to test my mettle against Mother Nature, I wanted good company.

Taking to heart William Blake's dictum that "Great things are done when men and mountains meet," I sent out the call of the wild to a few like-minded friends. After a flurry of phone conversations and last-minute plane reservations, our expedition crew was assembled: Besides my college chum and me, there were a radio station executive from California, a New York stockbroker who likes to unwind by trekking in Peru and the former Soviet Union, and my brother-in-law, a real-estate appraiser from South Carolina.

nytimes_articles.headline: Courier vs. Bruguera: Baseline Battery
nytimes_articles.abstract: Who's afraid of Jim Courier, the flint-eyed, two-time defending champion of the French Open who is back on the doorstep of a record third straight title?   Let's start off with Sergi Bruguera, Courier's Grand Slam neophyte challenger in a finale that promises to be chock-full of the baseline battery that has gotten them both where they are.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wine From Young Vines in Southern Ontario
nytimes_articles.abstract: NOT far from Niagara Falls in southern Ontario, venturesome wine-minded travelers will discover a region rich with young wineries. Like the Napa Valley of the early 1970's, the peninsula between Lake Ontario and Lake Erie is fertile territory for new, ambitious estates with big ideas. They are coaxing good wine from young grapevines and impatiently awaiting the nuances that come with older vines and more cellar experience.    Some 25 wineries -- 21 of them established since 1979 -- are cultivating grapes on 15,000 acres luxuriant with European vinifera vines. Entrepreneurs are so optimistic that applications for licenses to start 12 more wineries are pending before the provincial Liquor Control Board. Land values and planted acreage have risen. New buildings, German wine presses and sleek Italian bottling machines are appearing. And rising reputations are nudging revenues upward: Since 1990, sales of the peninsula's premium wines have increased 100 percent.

nytimes_articles.headline: Susan B. Titman, Peter S. Hedges
nytimes_articles.abstract: Susan Bruce Titman, a daughter of John and Narcissa Titman of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Peter Simpson Hedges, a son of the Rev. Robert B. Hedges of San Angelo, Tex., and Carole Hedges of New York. The bridegroom's father, a retired Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at St. James Church in Woodstock, Vt.   The bride, an actress with the Circle Repertory Company in New York, performs as Susan Bruce. She graduated from the University of Michigan and received a master's degree in fine arts from New York University. Her father is a vice president in New York at Home Box Office, the cable television network. Her mother, now retired, lectured in New York on the theater. The bride's maternal grandfather, the late Rev. Dr. V. Carney Hargroves, was president of the Baptist World Alliance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rifka Milder, Robert Sherman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rifka Jayne Milder, a daughter of Sheila Milder and Jay Milder, both of New York, was married on Monday to Robert Peter Sherman, a son of the late Gordon and Corinne Sherman. Rabbi Shira Milgrom performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.   Mrs. Sherman, 30, is a painter and the president of the Rifka Tie Company, a necktie designer in New York. She graduated from the California Institute of the Arts. Her father, a painter, retired as a professor of art at the City University of New York. Her mother is a painter and an art teacher at Junior High School 104 in Manhattan.

Philip Byrum performed the ceremony at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Wilson.   Mrs. Beermann is the head of client relations at Christie's East, the New York auction house. She graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Her father is the owner and the chief executive of the Nordic Group Inc., a refrigerated warehouse and distribution company in Wilmington. Her mother is a poet.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kindergarten's 111th Story Ends Happily
nytimes_articles.abstract: Arms waving and feet kicking, the costumed kindergartners at Public School 95 danced merrily onto a small wooden stage and crooned "Razzle Dazzle" and "Ease On Down the Road" -- songs that echoed eerily last week through their Brooklyn elementary school auditorium and the memories of onlookers.    Three months ago the children began rehearsing those songs as they stood shivering on the observation deck of the World Trade Center, awaiting rescue after a bomb exploded 110 floors below.

nytimes_articles.headline: Beware Neatness; It Can Be Terminal
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Sara and Marty Stein built their house here 12 years ago, they carved out a spot in the midst of red cedars, cat brier, multiflora roses, poison ivy and bittersweet. They kind of liked it that way.   "We thought our garden would end right here at the edge of the patio," said Ms. Stein, the author of the recently published "Noah's Garden" (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95). "We thought we'd just get somebody to mow."

nytimes_articles.headline: They Had Wings of Angels
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lynn Johnson and Michael O'Leary's EN ROUTE: Label Art From the Golden Age of Air Travel (120 pp., Chronicle, paper, $14.95) is a charmer, made up of very little (but always useful) text and page after page of exact color replicas of the labels produced by the airlines in the early decades to adorn one's luggage and service one's ego. Curiously, though flying was then more primitive, it was also more comfortable. In 1934, American Airlines coaxed Douglas Aircraft into coming up with something that would be called a DC-3. This pleasure dome would carry 14 passengers, with one berth each, from New York to Los Angeles. Before then, the trip took 25 hours and required 15 stops. Now you stopped only three times, and were there in 17 hours and 30 minutes. The volume's endpapers invoke the view-from-the-air of the modernist T.W.A. The graphic shows us two routes from west to east. To fly to Europe meant landings at Newfoundland, Ireland and Paris or Newfoundland, the Azores and Lisbon. It is the curse of the jet that except when traveling to the Far East one is never in it long enough to eat, drink, be merry and sleep. The label art reminds us at once of the airlines' utilitarian beginnings ("Hoosier Airplane Lines. 1923 Charter. 1924 Air Taxi. Serving Fort Wayne, Muncie, Indianapolis, Vincennes and Terre Haute. 'Silver Wings,' Operator") and of the ends they would go to in trying to make you feel loved. "American Flagship Skysleeper" wasn't a bag tag -- that was the legend painted on the hull of the DC-3. When ux and I went off on our wedding trip in 1950, we rented the tail end of the Pan Am DC-4, a mini-suite. Price? $150. . . . The old tags, it transpires, are valuable, so have a look in your attic.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Mortgage Hurdle Blocks Some Co-ops Sales
nytimes_articles.abstract: FOR Dianne Landi, home is a bird, a one-bedroom bird with long, slender wings and a large, curved beak.    When she and her then-newlywed husband, Anthony Denza, bought it six years ago, the co-op in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn was the first leg of their flight plan for family and future. But now the couple have a 4-year-old daughter, and Ms. Landi is expecting twins in October. They would like to sell their apartment and move to larger quarters; in fact they have been trying to sell it for two years. But they cannot.

nytimes_articles.headline: BOLIVIA TO VOTE FOR ITS PRESIDENT
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bolivians vote for a new President on Sunday, no small feat for a country that has a history of more military coups and dictatorships than any other in Latin America.   If, as predicted, the election goes off without violence and significant fraud, it will usher in the fourth consecutive civilian government since 1982, a remarkable period of stability for this nation. From 1964 to 1982, it had 16 governments, 14 of them military.

nytimes_articles.headline: Alexandra Golby, Jonathan Zeitlin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Golby of Peapack, N.J., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Jacqueline Golby, to Jonathan Henry Zeitlin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Zeitlin of Waban, Mass. A June 1994 wedding is planned.   Ms. Golby, 25, is a third-year medical student at Stanford University. She and her fiance, 28, graduated cum laude from Yale University. Her father is president and chief executive of the International Center in New York Inc., which helps newly arrived foreigners adjust to life in New York. Her mother, Monique Golby, is an art dealer in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Paterson Journal;
Dream of Creating Artists' Colony Meets Reality
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN Paterson created the 119-acre Great Falls Historic District in 1970, the plans included converting two 19th-century silk mills to artists' housing in 1983. Urban planners said that artists living, working and selling in the rugged old brick buildings would add life to the dilapidated factory district along the Passaic River.

They said the area would resemble the Old Torpedo Factory in Alexandria, Va., where clusters of strolling tourists find themselves unable to pass the open studios and display areas without buying.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fonteyn: Her Eyes Danced Too
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In his essay "Demonic Choreographers, Angelic Ballerinas"  [ May 9 ] , Jack Anderson says that Margot Fonteyn "could wobble in Odile's virtuoso passages" in "Swan Lake." It is true that Fonteyn was no fouette whiz. But I defy almost anyone out there today to convey the wicked seductiveness of Odile as Fonteyn could with her eyes alone. Most dancers nowadays are content to be a vamp in the role, forgetting that Odile must convey some of the quality of Odette.

nytimes_articles.headline: Booze in America, Stirred but Not Shaken
nytimes_articles.abstract: William Grimes, a cultural news reporter for The New York Times, has written a perceptive, informative and sometimes amusing account of the shifts and swings in American drinking fashions. From the beginning, he tells us in STRAIGHT UP OR ON THE ROCKS: A Cultural History of American Drink (Simon & Schuster, $18), this was a tippling country. The colonists displayed a knack for experimentation and improvisation, making alcoholic drink from "anything that would ferment." Beer, cider and especially rum were consumed with gusto and in a myriad of combinations with other ingredients. As America pushed westward, rum gave way to whisky, and the national appetite increased. Liquor was considered a health-giving beverage, and, Mr. Grimes reports, "At least one 19th-century insurance company imposed a surcharge on abstainers, regarded as weak and weedy, and unquestionably a bad health risk." The 19th century saw the rise of the saloon and the emergence of bartending as an honorable and highly respected profession. The later part of the century saw the birth of most of the classic cocktails -- including the martini, the manhattan and the old-fashioned. Prohibition "turned a lot of beer and wine drinkers into whisky drinkers." Gin, once a drink for down-and-outers, became "the spirit of the age." The period following Repeal has been, in the author's view, "a dreary saga of industry consolidation, mass marketing of image, and anxious trend-watching. The cocktail has suffered as a result." And what is the prognosis for the future of the cocktail? Mr. Grimes finds hope in two disparate groups: immigrants, rum and tequila drinkers who may "impart new vigor" to the cocktail; and yuppies, whose status-seeking insistence on "the best" disdains the blandness of blended whiskies and watery beers. The author includes recipes for 110 cocktails, both classics and worthy newcomers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Julie Miner, Stephen Ferzoco
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Julie Miner, the daughter of Jerry and Lydia Miner of Syracuse, was married yesterday to Dr. Stephen Ferzoco, a son of Bruno and Maria Ferzoco of Dedham, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Alan Mermann, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony in Hendricks Chapel at Syracuse University. The Rev. John Buehler, a Roman Catholic priest, was also in attendance.   Dr. Miner, 27, is keeping her name. She is to begin a residency this month in obstetrics and gynecology at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, where her husband is to begin a residency in surgery. She graduated from Brown University, and she and her husband received their medical degrees from Yale University.

Ms. Callahan, who is keeping her name, is a clerk for Judge Richard Newman of State Superior Court in Newark. She and her husband graduated from the Catholic University of America, where he also received a law degree. She received a law degree from Seton Hall.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Focus: Brentwood, Calif.;
Tenfold Growth for a Tiny Bay Area City?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JUST two weeks after the City Council of this farming community 40 miles east of San Francisco gave its approval to the largest residential development in local history -- a 1,031-house subdivision by A.G. Spanos Construction Company of Stockton -- it approved the second-largest. It will have 940 houses. Hancock Construction Company of Saratoga is the builder. 

Still to come is a proposal by the Cowell Foundation, a San Francisco charitable organization, to develop the 4,900-acre Cowell Ranch adjacent to this city into a 7,500-home community complete with schools, parks and retail and employment centers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dollar Gains In Finland
nytimes_articles.abstract: American visitors to Finland this year will find many prices dramatically lower than two years ago, thanks to a sharp drop in the value of the Finnish currency and a recession in that country.   According to a study conducted at the end of 1992 by Suomen Gallup Oy, a Finnish polling organization, which compared the prices for such staples as hotel rooms and a McDonald's Big Mac in 12 Western European capitals, Helsinki fell below the median on all types of lodging and most restaurant purchases, as well as train travel and airline tickets. Exceptions included taxi fares, car rental and food bought at a grocery.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, an article on May 23 about the British royal family referred incorrectly in some copies to the son of Queen Elizabeth, besides Prince Charles, who has had marital troubles. He is Prince Andrew, not Prince Edward.

nytimes_articles.headline:
OUTDOORS;
Tuning Up With the Bankside Orchestra of the Green Drake
nytimes_articles.abstract:
I checked my watch shortly after arriving at my chosen pool near Fish's Eddy on the East Branch of the Delaware river. It was 7:45 P.M., early enough for me to figure out what I'd forgotten before I was rigged up and standing in the water. One of the best features of fishing the green drake spinner fall, which will occur on local waters until the middle of this month, is that it's almost impossible to show up late for the event. As long as you arrive without your headlights on, you're early.

Half an hour later, I sat down on a log and poured a cup of coffee from my thermos. It was unseasonably cool for the first of June, and the bankside orchestra was in no mood to play this evening. I had heard that there had been great falls of spinners here over the last few evenings. I hoped there would be at least one more.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jeanne M. Arney, Douglas A. Muller
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jeanne Marie Arney, an assistant treasurer at the Bank of New York, was married yesterday to Douglas Andrew Muller, a vice president in the corporate finance division of the Chase Manhattan Bank, in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Sheffield performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Morristown, N.J.   Mrs. Muller graduated from Skidmore College and received an M.B.A. from New York University. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Terry O. Arney of Waterford, Va. Her father is a technical director at the Science Applications International Corporation, a technicalconsulting company in McLean, Va.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Long Island Q&A;: Jerome Swartz;
Bar Codes and Other Technology Leaps
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JEROME SWARTZ, chairman of Symbol Technologies of Bohemia, has used his knowledge of lasers to create a success story of startling proportions.

Mr. Swartz was a co-founder of Symbol Technologies in 1973, just as bar codes were gaining universal acceptance. The company's hand-held scanners garner two-thirds of their market, with a global share of 40 percent.

nytimes_articles.headline: A 300th Anniversary for Philipsburg
nytimes_articles.abstract:
PHILIPSBURG MANOR in North Tarrytown will celebrate its 300th anniversary on June 19 and 20, and the program will feature some typical events, typical, that is, for the late 17th century and early 18th century.

On those days, children will play with hoops; adults will compete in a tug of war and the music of the hurdy-gurdy, a hand organ, will fill the air. The food will be reminiscent of the year 1693: cold lemon-cucumber soup, whole wheat bread baked with wheat ground at the Philipsburg mill, grilled sausage and orange cookies (commemorating William of Orange). Soft drinks dispensed from a Colonial-style tavern will also be available.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins and Council Face Fiscal Maw's 300 Million Sharp Teeth
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sky was dark and menacing over Lower Manhattan yesterday, but it was no match for the gloom inside City Hall, where New York's political leaders worked behind closed doors to scale back the size of the municipal government by a hefty $300 million.   Cutting funds for valued services like day-care, summer school and homeless drop-in centers is never appealing to elected officials. But Mayor David N. Dinkins, Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and the 50 other members of the Council no doubt feel particularly vulnerable doing it now, just months before they will ask voters to re-elect them.

nytimes_articles.headline: E. D. Nickerson, J. H. Seltzer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth Dey Nickerson, the daughter of Mrs. William M. Riegel of Memphis, and William H. Nickerson 3d of Plymouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Howard Seltzer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Seltzer of Philadelphia. Steven Boyan, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, officiated in Mount Vernon Park in Baltimore.   Ms. Nickerson, who is 30, is keeping her name. She is a manager of health communications programs at the Center for Communications Programs at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, which promotes family planning in developing countries through the news media. She graduated from Georgetown University and received a master's degree in international development from Tufts University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Whale Watching
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: The Q & A column on May 16 contained a request for information on whale watching, which was followed by a long list of ports, including the Okeanos Foundation sailings from Hampton Bays, L.I.   Two years ago my boyfriend and I went on a whale-watching trip with this organization after having read about it in The Times. We took Dramamine before boarding, anticipating that there might be some queasiness, but we were never so sick in our lives. More than 75 percent of the passengers were just as sick. Old people, young people and kids were vomiting profusely almost the entire time.

nytimes_articles.headline: Freemasons Begin to Lift the Veil of Arcana
nytimes_articles.abstract: After years of being known as a reclusive, secretive society, the American Freemasons have begun to open the door to the public a little. The reasons are simple: they have developed some important enemies and they are running out of members.   Because national membership has declined from 4.1 million in 1959 to an aging 2.4 million today, the fraternal order began a renewal campaign two years ago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tribute to a 'Populist of the Highest Order'
nytimes_articles.abstract: WITH poetry, original dance compositions and emotional tributes, members of the world of modern dance recently honored the long and still active career of Bessie Schonberg, one of its revered leaders.   Gathered in a dance studio at Sarah Lawrence College here, the crowd of about 60 sometimes tearful alumni, dance professionals and academics watched as the studio -- in which Miss Schonberg often taught as the director of the college's dance department from 1938 to 1973 -- was officially named the Bessie Schonberg Dance Theater.

nytimes_articles.headline: Aspin Meets Russian in Bid to Take Ukraine's A-Arms
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stepping up the American campaign to persuade the Ukrainians to give up their nuclear weapons, Defense Secretary Les Aspin came here today to discuss with Russia a new plan to dismantle Ukraine's nuclear missiles and place their warheads under international supervision.    Mr. Aspin met with the Russian Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev. The plan is intended to resolve a Russian-Ukrainian dispute on how to deal with the warheads that would be removed from Ukraine's missiles if Ukraine gave up its nuclear arms.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cold Feet in the Senate
nytimes_articles.abstract: The weather outside the Capitol is warming up with the approach of summer. But inside some Senate Democrats are getting cold feet about serious political reform. The sticking point is public financing of elections. Unless President Clinton and Senate Democrats who understand the public's disgust at the present system now stand firm, a critical component of reform could be lost.   The issue will be joined in earnest this week when the Senate resumes debate on Mr. Clinton's proposed campaign finance reform. It's a promising bill that would curb reliance on special interests and foster greater competition by establishing a system of spending limits and partial public financing for House and Senate campaigns.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Indie' Rock Settles Into the Executive Suite
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jim Dunbar doesn't come across as a typical music industry bigwig. Instead of a business suit, he's likely to wear worn-out jeans, a T-shirt and a black leather jacket to work. He doesn't talk numbers or profits, and he doesn't hype, but he tends to launch into long, elaborate yarns about how he was once suspended from his job as a disk jockey for not letting the D.J. after him onto the air. Mr. Dunbar's idea of a high-powered lunch spot is Prime Burger, a crazy old 40's-style diner in midtown Manhattan, where swinging table-trays are attached to the chair arms and red meat for two (including fries on the side) comes in at well under $20.    As an A & R (artists and repertory) executive at Columbia, Mr. Dunbar is responsible for recruiting hip, challenging and (it is hoped) potentially profitable young bands to the label. His biggest assets for the job, he says, are his long, stringy hair hanging down almost to his waist and his thick, uncombed beard. Grabbing a fistful of locks, he grins and says: "This is my coat and tie. I can walk into any club in the world and go backstage and start rapping with the band. They're not afraid of me, because I look like one of them."

nytimes_articles.headline: Commercial Property: Bryant Park; Once Anathema, Now a Midtown Marketing Tool
nytimes_articles.abstract: CONVENTIONAL wisdom says nobody is getting higher rents for commercial space today than they did a few years ago. But don't tell that to Tom Kelly.   Mr. Kelly is a senior vice president of Mountain Development Corporation, which owns the Beaux Arts, the landmarked office building at the southeast corner of 40th Street and Avenue of the Americas. Until a year or so ago, four of the building's 10 floors were empty and, at asking prices of about $19 a foot, tenants were barely nibbling.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Man Who Reinvented the Louvre
nytimes_articles.abstract: By common consent, "The Century of Titian" at the Grand Palais is just about the most beautiful exhibition of European Old Master paintings and drawings that ever was put together. There are two basic reasons for this. One is that in the context of Titian and his precursors, friends, rivals, emulators and successors -- among them, Giovanni Bellini, Giorgione, Tintoretto and Veronese -- the show includes a remarkably high percentage of what everyone most wants to see.   No less important is the fact that the Grand Palais show, which continues through June 14, has not been dictated by some satrap of the seminar. It is an unscripted encounter in which works of art never before brought together in such numbers are left free to sort themselves out.

nytimes_articles.headline: On a Night Gone Wrong, Rivers Is What's Right
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was thrilling to see Doc Rivers hound Michael Jordan in the dying moments of the Knicks season here Friday night. And it was sad. Rivers wanted to give so much to win a championship for the Knicks, for himself. But by the end he just didn't have nearly enough to give.   On the night the Knicks expired, Rivers was everything that was ever right about the 1992-93, 60-victory Knicks. And wrong.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Quest to Conserve Electrical Power
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is unfortunate that "Lilco Ends a Homeowners' Rebate Program"  [ May 16 ]  further confuses a complicated issue. There are two central issues facing those of us active in the fields of energy analysis, conservation and demand-side management.  The first concerns are the quality, cost-effectiveness and long-term viability of utility demand-side management programs. The second is the methodology that the New York State Public Service Commission uses to allow Lilco and other New York State utilities to recover energy-conservation costs through the rate base. And while these two issues affect each other, it is important to make distinctions between the two.

nytimes_articles.headline: When All Roads Lead to Your Sofa
nytimes_articles.abstract: SUMMER is coming. It's in the air, on the street, in the loafers and in the hemlines. Summer is coming to Rome, and the prospect is terrifying, because when summer comes, so do visitors. I'm not talking about the Mom, Pop and old-fishing-buddy kind, but the kind who reincarnate dead acquaintanceships as true bondings once they discover your address is no longer a cobwebbed mailbox in some place even Indiana Jones wouldn't visit, but Rome, magical Rome, where the hotels are costly -- and doesn't old so-and-so live there now?   Since moving to Rome, I have discovered what seems to be the guiding principle of the world's floating population of unsolicited visitors: the popularity of the potential host rises in direct proportion to his or her proximity to the Pantheon.

WHERE OR WHEN

nytimes_articles.headline: End of Victory Drought Now in Sight for Stewart
nytimes_articles.abstract: Looking for his first victory since the 1991 United States Open, Payne Stewart had a late explosion of birdies and an eagle today to take a commanding lead into the final round of the Memorial Tournament.   The 36-year-old Stewart shot a four-under-par 67 for a 54-hole total of 14-under 203, which put him three strokes ahead of Paul Azinger, who had a 68 this afternoon. Bill Glasson is alone in third at 204.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Generational Question
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:    It is Elizabeth Kaye who is in desperate need of a reality check, as she is woefully unaware of her own implicit sexism ("The Sexes: Reality Dawns," May 9). Being recognized as a "mature woman" is hardly a "price of independence." It is older-generational spokeswomen like Ms. Kaye who continue to impair the women's movement with their infantile, nostalgic obsession with the quaintness of the sexual revolution. As a 21-year-old safe-sex veteran, I relish the thought of having something dangle from my vagina that is esthetically revolting, and I'm confident that I will feel at once "sexy and free," knowing that I am protecting my life and the life of my lover. ALISON MCDONALD New York

nytimes_articles.headline: Beijing Bans Trade in Rhino and Tiger Parts
nytimes_articles.abstract: China has published a ban on the trade of rhinoceros horns and tiger bones, coveted substances that have been essential to an enormously lucrative business in traditional Chinese medicines.   Tiger bones and rhinoceros horns have a special cachet among many Chinese, who believe that these exotic ingredients function as tonics that can heal and invigorate the body. The ban, if enforced, will be deeply resented by many but will help preserve the animals from poachers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Geraniums With That Continental Flair
nytimes_articles.abstract: FEW summer flowers do the yeomen work of geraniums. These sturdy plants combine well with other summertime flowers for bright displays in window boxes. Geraniums decorate tubs on the patio, and they provide bright accent color in borders where needed.   Geranium plants are rugged, too, and will survive the first blasts of cool weather. They keep on flowering until truly deep freezes finish them off. Each year sees brighter flower colors, stronger foliage and stems and unusual variety in geranium forms.

nytimes_articles.headline: Across the Computer Divide, The Nerds Face the Dummies
nytimes_articles.abstract: "DOS for Dummies," a how-to guide for using the software that runs most personal computers, seems to violate a time-honored tenet of business: never insult the customer.   Several publishers rejected the book, and once it was published leading bookstore chains initially declined to stock it. The first printing was a cautious 7,500 copies, and expectations were modest.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'There Is A Third Choice'
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As president of the International Design Conference in Aspen, I was saddened to read Herbert Muschamp's essay "Rocky Mountain Low: Aspen's Design Conference"  [ May 16 ] . He makes the assumption that there can be only two responses to a human-rights problem such as Colorado's Amendment 2: wholehearted endorsement or boycott. We believe there is a third choice. The civil-rights movement of the 1950's and 60's in the American South represents a viable alternative for changing unjust laws. While boycotts were a part of the movement, they were used selectively, against those directly responsible for discrimination.  The movement's primary focus was change through communication, education and voter registration.

nytimes_articles.headline: Visiting 'Jurassic Park' For Real
nytimes_articles.abstract: They're probably as close to the real thing as movie dinosaurs will get, moving as naturally as animals in a National Geographic special. The vegetarian dinosaurs nuzzle cute chicks, drool, snooze in the sun, roam savannas in picturesque herds and display distinctive personalities. The carnivores bare serrated teeth, fix baleful eyes on their human prey and splash their way across lush Hawaiian landscapes. All in all, the creatures in Steven Spielberg's big-budget science-fiction thriller "Jurassic Park," which opens on Friday, should, at the very least, amuse dinosaur lovers.   People watchers will have to make do with the performances by Sam Neill and Laura Dern as two young scientists in love, Jeff Goldblum as an eccentric mathematician, Sir Richard Attenborough as a billionaire -- "We saw him as a cross between Walt Disney and Ross Perot," Mr. Spielberg said -- and two small children.

nytimes_articles.headline: Correction
nytimes_articles.abstract: The diagram with this column last Sunday included a misplaced black king. It should have been on g8.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Experiment in Autobiography'
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Jill Johnston's provocative case for the emergence of autobiography as a literary genre "as persuasive as fiction" ("Fictions of the Self in the Making," April 25) brought to mind a prediction made 60 years ago by H. G. Wells -- a forecast for which the 20th-century prophet, so far as I know, has been given no credit. In his "Experiment in Autobiography" (1934), Wells expressed his determination to write "biographical and autobiographical matter" that was "so much more real and interesting and satisfying that I doubt if I shall ever again turn back towards The Novel." Wells excoriated "the race of silly young men who announce that they are going to write The Novel" and saw that "perhaps in 1965  [ these ]  foolish young men will all be trailing in the wake of Lytton Strachey and Philip Guedalla and announcing colossal biography-sequences. They will produce vast mosaics of pseudo-reality, galleries of portraits, presenting contemporary history in a state of exaltation."

nytimes_articles.headline: Salt Lake City Skiing Uphill on Bid
nytimes_articles.abstract: Salt Lake City, snubbed once before by the International Olympic Committee, has not lost a step. This quiet metropolis, nestled within the Wasatch and Oquir Mountains, is pressing ahead at a bustling pace with its bid for the 2002 Winter Games -- despite possible derailment again by the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.   At the United States Olympic Committee meetings here today, bid organizers unveiled a Utah Sports Development plan that would complete all facilities and bolster coaching staffs at the Winter Sports Park in time for the I.O.C. vote on June 16, 1995, in Budapest. The bid by Salt Lake City already has the endorsement of the U.S.O.C., and Salt Lake City organizers took many of the directors on a tour of facilities that are sprouting 15 miles east of downtown.

nytimes_articles.headline: Orr Says He Will Remain at Iowa State
nytimes_articles.abstract: JOHNNY ORR, who talked of quitting as the men's coach at Iowa State earlier this year, says he'll honor his contract with the Big Eight Conference school.   Orr signed a contract extension last year that calls for him to coach the Cyclones through the 1994-95 season. But when Iowa State recently shunned his application to become athletic director, Orr said he would quit if he could not agree with the school's choice of a successor for MAX URICK.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'On the Town' in Revival At Goodspeed Opera
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHY fight it? The Goodspeed Opera House restoration of "On the Town" is captivating. What Leonard Bernstein meant when he wrote of "the joy of music" is fully transmitted into the joy of a musical comedy. This -- pure, simple, sweet, sentimental and funny -- is how it used to be.    Bathed in a very real nostalgia, here is the "New York, New York" of old: Lindy's, Luchow's, the Roxy (the movie palace, not the disco or the deli). But not that old: The Hippodrome (the 5,000-seat showplace, not the garage) was razed. "Tobacco Road" was already closed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Update; Cleanup of Abandoned Tires Beginning in New York City
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York is beginning a $200,000 program to collect and dispose of thousands of abandoned tires as mounds of them continue to grow in some of the city's neglected neighborhoods.   Called the Waste Tire Management Program, the plan calls for the city's Departments of Transportation and Sanitation to collect junk tires from some 300 illegal dump sites in the five boroughs. Beginning in mid-July, about 150,000 tires are expected to be collected and placed on four city-owned lots for disposal by an outside vendor, city officials said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Fowlkes And Mr. Moon
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. George Allen Fowlkes of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Spencer Fowlkes to James Graham Moon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Derek J. Moon of London. An October wedding is planned.   Miss Fowlkes graduated from Denison University. She is a caterer in New York and Nantucket, Mass. Her father, a real estate investor in New York, is the president of the Episcopal Church Foundation and a trustee of the Episcopal Diocese of New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hillary Windolf and Kelly Koonce
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hillary Jane Windolf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Windolf of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Kelly Montgomery Koonce, a son of Mr. and Mrs. K. Terry Koonce of Mendham, N.J. Canon Leonard Freeman performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Short Hills, N.J.   Mrs. Koonce, 22, and her husband, 23, graduated from Drew University; she magna cum laude, he summa cum laude. She is to begin graduate studies in communication sciences and disorders at the University of Texas at Austin in the fall. Her father is the president of Bollinger Insurance, an insurance agency in Montclair. Her mother, Muriel Windolf, is an interior designer in Montclair.

nytimes_articles.headline: Visionary Design for Berlin's Workers
nytimes_articles.abstract: BERLIN is a city of fierce, often exact contradictions. It lies on a climatic fault line where westerly winds blowing off the North Sea meet dry winds blowing, reputedly, out of the Russian steppes. People look out their windows into claustrophobic courtyards and then spend their weekends walking through vast, forestlike parks. Architecturally, it is a city of confounding ugliness -- of once pompous prewar buildings with their now charred, or missing, or jarringly restored facades; of banal, poured-concrete apartments and office blocks on both sides of the former wall; of contemporary architectural experiments that can look like recent wounds surrounded by so many scars. It is also a city of exquisite, if infrequent, beauty. Karl Friedrich Schinkel's cool classicism, for instance. And the inspired, often utopian innovations of the 1920's -- many influenced by Schinkel -- are often, even in their postwar, reconstructed versions, still exciting and surprising. Schinkel's buildings, many of which are in the center of the city, are almost unavoidable, but the best examples of Weimar-era architecture are -- to my mind -- the great housing developments known as public-housing estates, or Gross-Siedlung. They are all in the outer districts of town, but easily reached by subway.    The first to be constructed -- and, at the time, the most famous -- was the "horseshoe," or Hufeisen, estate, one section of the Gross-Siedlung Britz, in the working-class borough of Neukolln, southeast of the city center. The Horseshoe Estate, built between 1925 and 1927, is so called because the focal point of its thousand or so dwellings is a horseshoe-shaped three-story apartment building. Three streets of one-family houses surround the horseshoe, and the boundaries of the estate are bordered, for the most part, by three-story apartment houses. Bruno Taut, Weimar Berlin's most productive architect, designed much of the project, including the horseshoe itself, but credit is also given to Martin Wagner, who designed the apartments on the estate's northern boundary. Wagner, as a member of the building society that financed the construction and, later, as Berlin's chief city planner, was the driving force behind the city's 1920's housing revolution.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Racing Can't Afford More Tragedies
nytimes_articles.abstract: HOW much more of this can racing take? This is the visceral response after watching Prairie Bayou break down in the Belmont yesterday.   The horse was then "humanely destroyed," as they say in racing, and they say it a lot these days.

nytimes_articles.headline: Susan Webb, Jean Dreyfus
nytimes_articles.abstract: Susan Patterson Webb, a managing principal at Paribas Capital Markets, was married yesterday to Jean Francoise Dreyfus, a vice president at Credit Suisse Financial Products Inc., both in New York. The Rev. David T. Lowman, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Covenant Presbyterian Church in Petersburg, Va. Cantor Fernand Peres took part in the ceremony.   Mrs. Webb-Dreyfus is the group head of the equity derivatives department of the New York securities branch of Banque Paribas of Paris. She graduated from the University of Virginia, from which she also received an M.B.A. She is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Webb of Petersburg.

nytimes_articles.headline: San Juan
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: The "What's Doing in San Juan" column (April 4) was filled with useful information on activities for prospective visitors to Puerto Rico.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cards for Calls On the Road
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE telephone debit card is coming to the United States. This card, which in France and Japan provides almost the only way to operate a pay phone, is creeping into, rather than exploding on, the United States market. But with the continuing activity of shoulder surfers, thieves who learn your telephone charge card number while you are using a pay phone and run up big bills with it, debit cards for use in the United States have appeal for people on the road. The obvious drawback is that you pay in advance, but if you lose the card, or its numbers are copied by a thief, all you lose is the value remaining on the card.    With the camp season upon us, the phone debit card may also look worthwhile to parents who want to give children a way to call from anyplace to anyplace, not just collect to home, but do not want their credit card numbers drifting around.

nytimes_articles.headline:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Baltimore;
Back on Track In Rustic Area
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN a secluded, rustic city neighborhood four miles north of downtown, a builder is completing the town-house project of a development group that went out of business two years ago.

Richmond American Homes of Fairfax, Va., a subsidiary of M.D.C. Corporation of Denver, a holding company largely involved in construction, is working on construction of the last 66 town houses there of a 120-home development begun by John W. Steffey Sr., a local real estate dealer, and Harry Hockman of Boca Raton, Fla., and Joseph Schwartz of South Palm Beach, Fla.

nytimes_articles.headline: Renu Nanda and Sanjoy Goyle
nytimes_articles.abstract: Renu Nanda, a daughter of Dr. Veena Nanda of West Simsbury, Conn., and Dr. Ravindra Nanda of Avon, Conn., was married yesterday in Simsbury, Conn., to Sanjoy Kumar Goyle, a son of Drs. Vimal and Krishan Goyle of Wichita, Kan. Punditji, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony at the Simsbury Inn.   Ms. Nanda, who is keeping her name, is an associate at the law firm of Hebb & Gitlin in Hartford. She and her husband graduated from Duke University and received law degrees from Boston University. Her father is a professor and chairman of orthodontics at the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington. Her mother is a periodontist in East Hartford and Bristol, Conn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Biking Along Michigan's Hilly Shores
nytimes_articles.abstract: ON the beach in Frankfort, Mich., where the western sky glows until 10 o'clock on July nights, a young woman in baggy white shorts was lashing a couple of mountain bikes to a signpost. She and some friends had just clambered off their boat from Chicago, she explained. Chicagoans have been coming to the upper reaches of their lake since the days before air-conditioning. These days, many of them bring their bikes.    My own was down the street, in the parking lot behind the Hotel Frankfort, on Main Street, about three blocks from the beach. This was the eve of my four-day, 225-mile solo, haphazard cycling tour and this town of about 1,600 was my starting point -- about 300 miles from Chicago, roughly at the base of the Leelanau Peninsula, which cuts 30-some miles north into Lake Michigan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Laurie Gordon, Kenneth Johnson
nytimes_articles.abstract: Laurie Cecile Gordon, an associate with the law firm of White & Case in New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth Alan Johnson, an associate at the law firm of Wiggin & Dana in New Haven. The Rev. Charles M. Cary performed the ceremony at the Westhampton (L.I.) Presbyterian Church.   Ms. Gordon, 30, is keeping her name. She graduated from the University of Delaware and received a law degree from Georgetown University. She is a daughter of Marlin Brown-Gordon of Tybee Island, Ga., and Gerald B. Gordon of Raleigh, N.C.

nytimes_articles.headline: Charles Is Superb Despite a Soggy Day
nytimes_articles.abstract: Persistent rain and slight wind produced generally mediocre scores today in the second round of the $550,000 Nynex Commemorative. But Bob Charles, who has had a number of remarkable rounds in winning this tournament twice, shot a four-under-par 66 on the 6,505-yard Sleepy Hollow Country Club course.   Charles had a share of the lead at four-under 136 with Chi Chi Rodriguez, who shot 70 this afternoon; Larry Gilbert, who carded 67, and Tom Aycock, who had 69. Gilbert and Aycock are looking for their first Senior PGA Tour victories while Charles and Rodriguez have combined for 41, with 2 of the 20 by Charles coming this season.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption with the Out There column on May 23, about fashion shows in China, referred incorrectly to the model wearing a Valentino dress. Her identity is unknown.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dick Gregory Is Back
nytimes_articles.abstract: NAME: Dick Gregory   IDENTITY: Trailblazing comedian, civil rights advocate and one-time Presidential candidate. Heads Dick Gregory Health Enterprises, which makes diet products. Father of 10.

nytimes_articles.headline: Signs of Blast Fading, but Tremors Remain
nytimes_articles.abstract: The spacious elevators, stuffed with executives and camera-toting tourists, are once again gliding like zippers up and down the towers of the World Trade Center. New windows have replaced shattered ones. Fresh paint covers smoke-stained walls.   Except for a few posters referring to "repairs" and a phalanx of guards checking new identification cards, there are few signs that just three months ago, a huge explosion ripped through the trade center's underground garage, killing six people and sending tens of thousands scrambling down smoke-filled stairwells to safety.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Party In the Garden
nytimes_articles.abstract: A gala celebration of the exhibition 'Latin American Artists of the 20th Century,' June 2 at the Museum of Modern Art.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cause and Effect
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In your interview with Jose Rivera, "Another Playwright Confronts an Angel and the Apocalypse"  [ May 16 ] , Mr. Rivera is quoted as saying, "We need to find new heroes and new myths for our society -- the old ones just aren't working. The God we know now is a right-wing, white male, corporate God, in whose world racism, sexism and political injustice are rampant. As the millennium nears, I am amazed these things are still valid."

nytimes_articles.headline: Books for Vacation Reading
nytimes_articles.abstract: Art, Music & Popular Culture   THE ART OF CELEBRATION: Twentieth-Century Painting, Literature, Sculpture, Photography, and Jazz. By Alfred Appel Jr. (Knopf, $35.) Modern times aren't all Eliot and Kafka, the author cheerfully argues; there's also Matisse, Astaire, Chaplin, Teddy Wilson and a whole raft of dedicated life affirmers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Leslie Wunderlich and James Simpson
nytimes_articles.abstract: Leslie Alexander Wunderlich, a daughter of Nancy Keiter of San Luis Obispo, Calif., and Herbert E. Wunderlich of Orange, Calif., was married yesterday to William James Simpson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Simpson of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Richard Reifsnyder performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the home of the bride's mother and her stepfather, Steven E. Keiter.

nytimes_articles.headline: HUT's, PUT's and Traction: TV-Programmer Talk
nytimes_articles.abstract: Every profession has its own jargon, but the catch phrases peculiar to the television business are peculiar indeed. At this time of year, when the networks solder together their fall prime-time schedules, the buzzwords are flying like spring pollen. A sampling:   AUSPICES: Writers or producers. As in, "This show has outstanding auspices." Some shows, like "Homicide," have better auspices than ratings.

nytimes_articles.headline: L.I.R.R. Lags On Dual-Mode Locomotives
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ALTHOUGH commuters riding diesel locomotives on the Long Island Rail Road have to change to electric trains before entering New York City, commuters upstate and in Connecticut have long enjoyed direct service on their entire systems, thanks to dual-mode locomotives that run on electric or diesel power.

For six years the L.I.R.R., along with its parent, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and another M.T.A. agency, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, has been developing dual-power locomotives. But after spending more than $12.3 million for three prototypes, direct service -- already a year behind schedule -- remains doubtful because of technical problems, flood damage, delays and cost overruns. Growing ridership on the diesel-powered Port Jefferson branch in the late 80's helped create a demand for direct service. By using dual-power technology, along with $2.27 million for double-decker cars, the railroad and the M.T.A. had hoped to increase the capacity of the line without the expense of electrifying east of Huntington, where the third rail ends.

nytimes_articles.headline: 12th Season for Early Music Festival
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Connecticut Early Music Festival celebrates its 12th season with a dozen concerts in eight locations, and an expansion of the term early music to encompass songs of Stephen Foster, even works for period instruments by seven contemporary composers.   The artistic directors, the flutist John Solum and the harpsichordist Igor Kipnis, help start the first recital -- recitals, actually, since the 6:15 P.M. Friday program in Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London will be repeated there at 8:30 that evening -- with music of Telemann, Handel, Quantz, Boismortier and Hotteterre.

nytimes_articles.headline: Black Is Voted Episcopal Bishop
nytimes_articles.abstract: Suffragan Bishop Clarence N. Coleridge was elected the 13th Bishop of the Episcopal diocese of Connecticut today, becoming the first black ever to lead Connecticut's 80,000 Episcopalians.    The election, held at Christ Church Cathedral, ended what had become a heated six-way race.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Quixotic Days and Nights of Jay Tarses
